awd_titl_txt: IDBR:  TYPE A: Multispectral laser 3D ranging and imaging system for plant phenotyping
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) to develop a multi-wavelength LASER ranging and imaging instrument for phenotyping plant shoots at the whole plant level. Producing enough food and energy for a world population likely exceeding 9.7 billion by 2050 is the greatest challenge facing agriculture. Compared to modern genomic sequencing technologies, plant phenomics lags behind in its capacity and throughput. The instrument developed in this research will alleviate this limitation, allow more efficient genotype-phenotype analysis, and ultimately catalyze the acceleration of crop improvements (in terms of yield and stress tolerance) to solve the looming global food security challenge. The project will foster a collaborative environment where the postdoc, graduate and undergraduate students will receive interdisciplinary training in plant biology, biological engineering, and computer science. The team will develop course materials that allow students in traditional plant biology to learn the new domain knowledge of sensing, instrumentation and data processing (this is a perceived gap in university plant biology curriculum). Discoveries from the project will be presented at international conferences on plant science and biological engineering and published in peer reviewed journals. The team will also collaborate with plant scientists at UNL and plant phenotyping groups around the world for the broad dissemination of the instrument. 

This instrument can simultaneously probe chemical properties of plants (such as water, nitrogen, and chlorophyll concentration) through LASER imaging and measure 3D plant structure (such as size and spatial orientation of individual leaves) through LASER ranging. Through these measurements, more parameters related to plant physiology and functions (such as photosynthesis and stomatal activity) can be extracted. All the parameters will be spatially co-registered, eliminating the need for tedious data fusion. New algorithms will be developed to process massive 3D LASER point clouds and reconstruct plant leaf and stem surfaces. The performance of the instrument will be rigorously validated through a series of experiments involving stressed versus healthy plants. Taken together, the instrument provides transformative improvement in both capacity and throughput for plant shoot phenotyping, which will in turn benefit many fields of basic and applied plant biology research.

por.por_cntn:
This project designed and created a laser ranging and multispectral imaging instrument for plant phenotyping. New instruments to measure novel traits of plants with increased speed and capacity are important to advance the high throughput plant phenotyping research. This instrument was developed with the intent to enable simultaneous, rapid, and non-destructive measurements of a number of structural (in 3D) and biochemical properties of plants.

The development of the instrument included both hardware and software. The major components of the hardware comprised of a 2D laser scanner, a custom-made multispectral imaging system with six spectral channels, a precision rotation stage, other supporting electronics, and a computer. The plant was placed on the rotation stage and continuously rotated for 360 degrees. In the meantime, the laser scanner and the imaging system scanned the plant at different angles. The data collection time for each plant was less than 180 seconds.

The software of the instrument included a program written in LabVIEW for the hardware control, timing, and measurement data acquisition. The program saved all the raw measurement data, including the 3D point cloud in the original instrument coordinate system and the multispectral images of the plant taken from different angles. The second part of the software was a program written in MATLAB to process the raw measurement data and extract the target plant traits. The surfaces of the plant leaves and stem were reconstructed from the 3D point cloud, and plant morphological traits including leaf areas, leaf inclination angle, leaf angular distribution, and stem thickness were extracted. The multispectral images of the plants were segmented and the average plant pixel intensity was extracted to develop predictive models for the biochemical traits of leaf chlorophyll concentration, nitrogen content, and water content. 

Agriculturally important plant species, maize and sorghum, were used to test and validate the performance of the instrument. Three validation experiments were conducted by comparing the instrument-measured plant traits against the values derived through destructive sampling and lab analysis. The results showed strong correlations between the instrument measurements and ground truth values across these validation experiments: R2 > 0.90 for leaf area; R2 > 0.72 for leaf inclination angle; R2 = 0.63 for stem diameter; R2 > 0.88 for leaf chlorophyll concentration; R2 = 0.91 for leaf water content; and R2 > 0.83 for leaf nitrogen content.

The project led to six peer-reviewed journal articles, one referred conference paper, and one master thesis.  

The project provided training for one postdoc research associate, four graduate students, and three undergraduate student workers. The project supported the development and launch of one graduate-level course (Advanced Sensing in Agriculture and Natural Resources) in the Department of Biological Systems Engineering (BSE) at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL). This course was taught in the spring of 2017 and 2019 to a total of 18 graduate students from BSE, Department of Agronomy & Horticulture, and School of Natural Resources (all at UNL).

This project greatly impacted the development of NU-Spidercam (https://ard.unl.edu/phenotyping/field-phenotyping-facility), a large-scale, integrated sensing and robotic facility for high-throughput field phenotyping at UNL. The project prepared the team well for hardware and software development of the system. NU-Spidercam has become a critical research infrastructure for plant phenotyping, supporting a large number of scientists to conduct phenotyping projects, as well as serving as a training ground for many young scientists in the related disciplines.

High throughput plant phenotyping is a cutting-edge research field that bears promise to further enhance crop yield/quality and ensure global food security. This project developed a new instrument that allows researchers to collect phenotypic traits of plants more rapidly and comprehensively. This would further enable more effective utilization of plant's genetic data and a faster pace of crop improvement, for cultivars of higher yield potential, more stress-tolerant, and resilience to the future climate conditions.
